titleStmt.title: Hybridizing sine cosine algorithm with differential evolution for global optimization and object tracking

analytic.title: Hybridizing sine cosine algorithm with differential evolution for global optimization and object tracking

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Highlights
div.p: ï‚· A novel Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm is introduced for global optimization and object tracking. ï‚· The proposed hybrid algorithm has better capability to escape from local optima with faster convergence. ï‚· The performance of the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm was better than with other state-of-the-art metaheuristic algorithms. ï‚· The hybrid SCA-DE algorithm is applied for visual tracking as a real thought-provoking case study to demonstrate and verify the performance of this algorithm in practice.

div.p: As the above Eqs. (5)(6)(7) show, there are four key parameters in SCA: ğ‘Ÿ 1 ; ğ‘Ÿ 2 ; ğ‘Ÿ 3 and ğ‘Ÿ 4 . Parameter ğ‘Ÿ 1 gives the movement direction (or region) of the following positions which could either be in the space amidst the solution and destination or outside it. ğ‘Ÿ 2 parameter details how distant the movement should be outwards or towards the destination. ğ‘Ÿ 3 parameter carries a random load for the destination in order to stochastically de-emphasize (ğ‘Ÿ 3 <1) or emphasize (ğ‘Ÿ 3 >1) the influence of destination in describing the distance. ğ‘Ÿ 4 parameter switches appropriately from sine to cosine or vice versa in Eq. (7).

div.head: Differential Evolution
div.p: The Differential Evolution (DE) [8] algorithm is a population-based algorithm like genetic algorithm using similar operators: mutation, crossover, and selection. The main difference between the algorithms is that genetic algorithm relies on crossover while DE relies on mutation operation. This main process of DE is based on the differences of randomly sampled pairs of solutions in the population. DE relies on a randomly initialized population comprising of
div.formula: N p individuals. Each individual ï» ï½ x x x x X n i i i i ,..., , ,3 2 1
div.p: ï€½ is a vector of n dimensions. DE relies on three operators that are repeated for a maximum number of iterations.

div.head: A. Mutation
div.p: This operation creates a mutant vector ui by selecting components from a randomly selected vector xa and the difference of two other randomly generated vectors xb and xc . Mathematically,
div.formula: ï€¨ ï€© x x beta x u c b a i ï€­ ï€ª ï€« ï€½ (9)
div.p: where,
div.formula: i c b a ï‚¹ ï‚¹ ï‚¹
div.p: , beta is a random number used to control the perturbation size of the mutation. Here, xa is known as a base vector.

div.head: B. Crossover
div.p: This operator creates a trial vector vi by crossing over to mutant vector and target vector (another randomly generated vector). In other words, the trial vector is generated by randomly selecting components from the mutant vector ) (u i and target vector ï€¨ ï€© xi using a probability factor p CR . Mathematically,

div.head: C. Selection
div.p: This operator chooses the better offspring among vi and xi using their fitness which guarantees that each iterations solution is better than the solution obtained in the previous iteration. Mathematically,

div.head: Proposed Algorithm
div.p: The standard SCA algorithm has exhibits good performance on some unimodal benchmark function problems. However, when facing complex multimodal functions, this algorithm often converges to a local minimum quickly, missing better opportunities [40]. This provides the possibility of hybridizing SCA with other techniques.

div.head: Search characteristics of DE
div.p: In order to prevent premature convergence of SCA, DE as a local search operator [9] is introduced before to generate a new population. Firstly, a poll set which depends on each individual ï» ï½

div.head: Stability analysis of DE
div.p: The Von Neumann stability analysis of finite difference scheme [41] is used for performing the stability analysis of DE algorithm, to find a suitable value of mutation scaling factor beta in DE algorithm. The mutation strategy namely DE/rand/1 is considered from Eq. (9): x b are also randomly selected individuals from the current population. We assume the value of beta to be always non-negative, without loss of generality.

The experiment is conducted with 30 independent runs for all benchmark functions, average, standard deviation, median and worst of the best-so-far solution in the last iteration are reported in Tables 3 and4. The parameter standard deviation also reflects the stability of an algorithm, by observing standard deviation values in Tables 3 and4, we can say that DE gives stable solutions for all test functions.
Parameter Selection of DE

div.head: Number of population (NP)
div.p: According to [43], the reasonable value of NP should be chosen to be in between 3n and 8n.

The convergence time and dimension of the problem should be considered while choosing the values of NP. Large NP values may compromise computation time and become redundant. Whereas, low NP may cause premature convergence and falling into local minima. Hence, the value of NP is chosen as 30 for all computational experiments in this paper.

div.head: Mutation scale factor (beta)
div.p: The range of beta is generally considered as [0, 1]. When 1 ï€¾ beta , solutions tend to consume large computation time and are less reliable [44]. When 1 ï€½ beta , the discontinuity limits the possible trial vectors generated by reducing the number of mutants by half. Sufficient diversity is required to prevent the stagnate condition in DE. In stagnate condition, the solution falls into local optima and DE can no longer be in a position to explore an improved solution. By considering random values of beta , more possibilities to the vector differentials can be obtained [44], which increases the number of potential trial vectors. In this paper, the beta values are randomized between 0.2 and 0.8, as the values less than 0.4 and greater than 1 are considered mostly ineffective [45].

div.head: Crossover rate
div.formula: ) ( p CR In DE,
div.p: p CR corresponds to the user defined parameter which controls the diversity of the population and helps the algorithm to escape from local minima. It is found that low p CR values are the most effective values [44]. We have performed the experiment with 30 independent runs with 0.1 increment in p CR by keeping beta as constant and mean fitness value of 30 independent runs is recorded for all benchmark functions, but we have plotted results only for F1, F6, F7 and F18 in Fig. 3. Based on the experiments, as we increase p CR from 0.1 to 0.2 there is an improvement in mean fitness value, but after that performance is almost constant. In this paper,

div.head: Sensitivity to parameters for DE
div.p: To investigate the impact of population size on the performance of DE, we have performed the experiment with 30 independent runs with 10 increment in the population size (NP) as given in literature [46]. The investigations are conducted on functions F2, F11, F16 and F17 which are unimodal and multimodal benchmark functions. When solving these functions F2, F11, F16 and F17, increasing the population size up to 30 can enhance the diversity of the algorithm and can, therefore, lead to better results as shown in Fig. 4. But any further increment in population size after 30 the performance is almost constant. To balance the computational burden and the algorithm performance, 30 population size is used in this paper.

For [46]. These investigations are conducted on functions F1, F6, F14 and F18. The mean values of 30 independent runs are plotted in Fig. 5. From Fig. 5, there is no significant difference in results. DE as a local search operator is not sensitive to the initial values of these parameters, which is an advantage of DE. This is just why DE as a local search operator is adopted in our framework.

div.head: Hybrid SCA-DE
div.p: The hybridizing SCA with DE (Hybrid SCA-DE) is introduced in details in this section. In SCA, the way an algorithm moves towards the next position is based on random and adaptive variables; therefore, a satisfactory solution cannot always be found every time. To overcome this disadvantage, some genetic reproduction mechanisms have been added to SCA approach. For some cases, SCA is capable of making full use of the population knowledge and has proven good performance on some benchmark functions. However, sometimes, SCA may not lead to optimal solutions to complex problems. To further enhance the exploitation of SCA, a more focused differential evolution algorithm is incorporated into the SCA to form a new Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm. The mutation and crossover operators are used to generate a new position for SCA. For a minimum problem, if the newly generated solution has a smaller fitness, it will be in place of the old one. In other words, it can be considered as a solution to the next generation.

In Hybrid SCA-DE, a standard SCA algorithm is utilized to search globally for the purpose of making most solutions move toward a more promising area. After the exploration stage, DE algorithm is utilized to search locally with a small step to get the final best solution. Based on the mainframe of Hybrid SCA-DE, the SCA emphasizes the diversification at the beginning of the search with a big step to explore the search space extensively and evade trapping into local optima, while later DE algorithm focuses on the intensification and lets the individuals move toward the best solution at the later stage of the optimization process. Also, this method can cope with both global and local search effectively.

Initially, it evaluates the fitness of each vector and in obtaining the best solution (destination position) which is assigned to SCA as the position of the destination point in Eqs. ( 5) and (6). DE is used as an intermediate algorithm to improve the worst results obtained using SCA between iterations. Over a series of iterations, the position of every individual in the SCA is updated using Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6). Then we update to new positions using Eqs. ( 9) to (11), respectively. Once the series of iterations is completed, it returns the best solution of the function.

div.head: Steps of proposed Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm
div.p: Conceptualizing all facts discussed above, the clear steps of the proposed Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm is presented below. Moreover, the detailed pseudocode and flowchart of Hybrid SCA-DE are also outlined in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7.
Step 1: Initialize of N individuals randomly as the vector at the start of the algorithm

div.head: Results and analysis
div.p: To check the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm is compared with twenty-three popular and classical benchmark functions employed by many researchers [39,[47][48][49]. These benchmark functions (shown in Table 1) can be categorized into three groups: Unimodal, Multimodal high-dimensional, and fixed dimension (low-dimensional) multimodal benchmark functions.

Hybrid SCA-DE, SCA, PSO, DE and TLBO algorithms have several parameters that need to be initialized before running. Table 2 shows the initial values of the basic parameters for these algorithms. For Hybrid SCA-DE, the parameters taken are the combination of parameters from both SCA and DE.

The Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm and other algorithms (SCA, PSO, DE, and TLBO) are simulated thirty times on each of the twenty-three benchmark functions for comparison. The experimental results comprising several statistical parameters, such as average, standard deviation, median and worst of the best-so-far solution in the last iteration are reported. The results of the algorithms on all test functions are presented in Table 3 for dimension D=10 and Table 4 for D=30 for functions F1-F13. To verify the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, the same maximum number of iterations and population sizes are taken for the proposed and the existing algorithms (SCA, PSO, DE, and TLBO) to verify the efficiency of the proposed algorithm. The outcomes are averaged over thirty independent runs, and the best outcomes are shown in bold type in the Tables.
The unimodal functions have no local solution and there is only one global solution. Consequently, they are used to examine heuristic optimization algorithms in terms of convergence rate. Functions
div.formula: F F 7 1 ï€­
div.p: are unimodal functions, and the results for these unimodal functions are shown in Tables 3 and4. As can be seen in this tables, the Hybrid SCA-DE outperforms the other algorithms on five out of seven for D=10 and six out of seven for D=30 for the unimodal benchmark functions in terms of the mean, standard deviation, median, and worst value of the results. Therefore, this is evidence that the proposed algorithm has high performance in finding the global solution of unimodal benchmark functions.
For multimodal functions

with many local minima, the final results are more important because of this function can reflect the algorithm's ability to escape from poor local optima and obtain the near-global optimum. We have tested the experiments on

where the number of local minima increases exponentially as long as the dimension of the function increases. As the results of mean, standard deviation, median, and the worst value is shown in Tables 3 and4 the Hybrid SCA-DE performs better than the other algorithms on four out of six multimodal high-dimensional benchmark functions for D=10 and 30. 3 and4 through Figs. 9(a) and Fig. 9(b), it can be said that Hybrid SCA-DE is efficient at evading local minima with a good convergence rate for multimodal functions. Therefore, it can be stated that the Hybrid SCA-DE can balance exploration and exploitation properly for solving challenging problems.

Comparing algorithms based on mean, standard deviation, median, and worst value over 30 independent runs does not compare each of the runs. Therefore, it is still possible that the superiority occurs by chance despite its low probability in 30 runs. In order to compare the results of each run and decide on the significance of the results, the Wilcoxon statistical test was performed at 5% significance level and the p-values are reported in Table 5. For the statistical test, the best algorithm in each test function is chosen and compared with other algorithms independently. For example, if the best algorithm is Hybrid SCA-DE, a pairwise comparison is made between Hybrid SCA-DE/SCA, Hybrid SCA-DE/PSO, Hybrid SCA-DE/TLBO, and so on. Note that since the best algorithm cannot be compared with itself, N/A has been written for the best algorithm in each function which stands for Not Applicable.

As per the results in Table 5, p-values are much less than 0.05 for the Hybrid SCA-DE, which demonstrates that the superiority of this algorithm is statistically significant. For function F20, the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm provides p-value greater than 0.05. This shows that the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm is not significantly better on this function. Overall, these results show that Hybrid SCA-DE can outperform other algorithms in the literature. According to the NFL theorem [23], therefore, it has the potential to solve problems (of the types tested) that cannot be solved efficiently by other algorithms.

div.head: Sensitivity Analysis of Parameters
div.p: To investigate the impact of population size on the performance of SCA-DE, we have performed the experiment with 30 independent runs with 10 increment in the population size as given in literature [46]. The investigations are conducted on functions F1, F4, F18 and F23 which are unimodal and multimodal benchmark functions. When solving these functions F1, F4, F18 and F23, increasing the population size the performance of SCA-DE is almost constant as shown in Fig. 11. To balance the computational burden and the algorithm performance, 30 population size is used in this paper.

For [46]. These investigations are conducted on functions F1, F6, F16 and F21. The mean values of 30 independent runs are plotted in Fig. 12. From Fig. 12, there is no significant difference in results. Thus, by inheriting the merits of DE as a local search operator, SCA-DE is also not sensitive to the initial values of these parameters, which is an advantage of SCA-DE. This is just why DE as a local search operator is adopted in our framework.

div.head: Application of Hybrid SCA-DE for object tracking
div.p: Computer vision is an advanced field of science and technology that concentrates on methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding images. Computer vision, as a scientific discipline, is associated with the theory behind artificial systems which extracts the related information from images and also relates its theories and models in designing computer vision systems. Various forms of image data can be considered such as image segments from multiple cameras, video sequences, or complex data from the medical scanner. Many applications of computer vision include, video communication and compression, high-level video analysis, display technology, security and surveillance, traffic control, video editing, metrology, human-computer interfaces to medical imaging, navigation, and augmented reality [50,51]. In object tracking problem, firstly a state vector is used for defining the characteristics of target motion (state model) which include position, speed, scale, etc., and then the observation information (observation model), such as visual characteristics including color, shape, texture, etc., is established. Visual tracking remains a challenging problem despite significant evolution and research, since many decades [52][53][54][55][56].

div.head: Optimization-based tracking system
div.p: Optimization is the process of selecting best solution from a number of available alternatives with or without constraints. In this case, the tracking of an object in video sequences, or the issue of tracking the target in every image frame can be inferred as an optimization problem. The similarity function or fitness function can be defined as the observation distance between the candidate and target. A target can be tracked by either maximizing or minimizing the similarity function in the candidate solution. Hence, tracking, as an optimization problem, can be accomplished using different optimization methods.
A general optimization-based tracking architecture has been designed to compare the performance of optimization-based trackers, which can also be applied to other optimizers.

Tracking framework using the proposed Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm is designed as shown in Fig. 13. Fig. 13 describes the architecture, wherein the process starts with a target being, chosen by the user, or detected by any distinct object detectors in the first frame. Then the state vector, which is defined in this work as ğ‘‹ = [ğ‘¥, ğ‘¦, ğ‘ ], is initialized. Where, (ğ‘¥, ğ‘¦) is the target's position in pixel coordinates and ğ‘ is a scale parameter that restrains the size of an object. After selection of target in first frame, the state vector is defined as ğ‘‹ 0 = [ğ‘¥ 0 , ğ‘¦ 0 , 1], where ğ‘¥ 0 , ğ‘¦ 0 is the target's initial location and ğ‘ = 1.0 specifies that there is no scale variation in the first frame.

New candidate state vectors are generated by using a dynamic model, after selecting a target and initializing the state vector. Dynamic model can be, constant velocity (CV) model, constant acceleration (CA) model, or random walk (RW) model. Assuming that the movement of the object is very little between the image frames, the random walk model is applied. An observation model is used to describe the correlation between the state of the object and its appearance. Choosing a good observation model is essential for any tracker, but a certain observation model cannot be chosen for all different tracking scenarios. In this work, search performance is considered as a priority and hence, a standard kernel-based spatial color histogram [53] is chosen as the observation model.
div.formula: Let ï» ï½ c i n i ,... 1 ï€½
div.p: be the normalized pixel locations of the target candidate, centered at c in the present frame.

div.p: , where hx and hy respectively denote the width and the height of the target's rectangle. The kernel based spatial color histogram is given by

div.p: is the normalization constant.

After determining the state vector, the similarity function is defined as the observation distance between target and candidate. Here, Bhattacharya coefficient is utilized to measure the similarity between two histograms [34,53].
div.formula: ï€¨ ï€© ïƒ¥ ï€­ ï€½ ï€½ N i i h i h h h B 1 2 1 2 1 ) ( ) ( 1 , (27
div.p: where N is the number of bins in the histograms and h1 and h2 are the histograms that are being compared. The coefficient ï€¨ ï€©
div.formula: h h B 2 1 ,
div.p: is big when the histograms are alike and small when they are very different.

The highlighted section of the flowchart shown in Fig. 13 represents the optimization process which forms the central part of optimization-based visual tracking algorithm. In this part, the Hybrid SCA-DE optimizer is adopted to select the candidate solution. In this way, the similarity function is maximized or minimized for tracking an object. Whenever the optimizer is probed for the target location, it displays the frame which indicates the location of the target. This entire process continues till no more frames are left available.

div.head: Experiments and discussions
div.p: To illustrate the efficiency of Hybrid SCA-DE, the proposed algorithm is compared with four other tracking algorithms including PF [37], SIFT [38], PSO [33] and BA [32]. Same target model and motion model are used for fair comparison.

In Hybrid SCA-DE, several experiments have been carried out and it is concluded that the population size of 15-20 is sufficient for most of the tracking problems. Two performance criteria are considered for performance evaluation of the tracker. The criteria considered are, a number of targets lost (the overlap region between ground truth and the bounding box is < 50%) and complexity of time (average time cost). Fig. 14 shows the performance of the tracker for different NP, which depicts that the tracking accuracy and time complexity is increased with NP. The optimum value of NP is considered to be 20 for all experiments, to maintain tracking accuracy and time complexity. Like in [36], three termination conditions are used to terminate the optimization process which are given as follows:
ï‚· The fitness of f worst (the worst solution) is good enough.

ï‚· The f best (best solution) is also good enough and the Euclidean distance between the best and the lowest solution (d) is below a certain threshold. ï‚· In this work, a maximum number of iterations is 100 and when it is reached the algorithm terminates.

From [53], the first two conditions depend mostly on Bhattacharya coefficient (fitness function). It is observed from the experimental simulations that the target is present, if the area of Bhattacharya coefficient is greater than 0.6. In order to guarantee that all candidates are close together with the best candidate near the target, we set the values of , f worst , f best and d to be 0.6, 0.8 and 5, respectively, in above termination conditions for better accuracy.

For comparing the results, some videos are selected and used for evaluation as taken in [57]. (Note: the tracking examples are available on the website http://visual-tracking.net). Fig. 15 shows some snapshots from given video clips. As seen from Table 6 the targets in these examples are suffering from various challenging factors. Tracking result of Hybrid SCA-DE for David, Panda, Subway, Mountain Bike, Boy, Crossing, Car and Couple Video sequences are shown in Fig. 16, and experimental results depict that the Hybrid SCA-DE-based tracker is capable of tracking a random target in various challenging situations.

For evaluating the accuracy of trackers, by identifying the center of the tracked target in each frame visually, the videos have been manually labeled. Then, the Euclidean distance between the center estimated by the trackers and the true center is calculated and is used as accuracy measure. The results of the comparison are shown in Fig. 17. In Fig. 17, the pink, green, black, blue and red lines show the tracking accuracy of the PF, SIFT, PSO, BA and Hybrid SCA-DE for the tracking examples, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 17 that the Hybrid SCA-DEbased tracker performs better in all challenging conditions. It is capable of successfully tracking the target during the whole tracking process.

In order to analyze the average time costs, the time complexity of the five trackers are calculated and the comparative results are shown in Table 7. As shown in Table 7, the Hybrid SCA-DE based tracker is capable of tracking faster compare to other four trackers on average.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: During the past twenty years, nature-based algorithms which are inspired by the behavior or phenomena of nature have become a hotspot in the optimization computation. This paper proposes a new optimization algorithm called Hybrid SCA-DE for solving optimization problems and object tracking. This algorithm is tested using Twenty-three eminent test functions. The experimental results show that the performance of the proposed algorithm is superior to that of the other existing algorithms in exploiting the optimum and it also has advantages in exploration. In future research, real-world functions can be used in order to determine whether the proposal provides good results in these cases with the parameters obtained in this study. In addition, the use of more dimensions up to 100, 500 or 1000 can also be studied. Also, this algorithm can be utilized for multi-objective functions. The performance measures show that the GOA-DE algorithm possesses a better capability to track an object as compared to other trackers. This work can be extended to track multiple targets and more cues will be added to track those targets. 5) and ( 6) on the next position [39] Fig. 2 Sine and cosine functions with the dimension in [-2, 2] tolerate a solution to go beyond (outside the space among them) or around (inside the space among them) the destination [39].

all computational experiments. This is because throughout the experiments for the different benchmark functions,

figure.head: F F 23 14 ï€­
figure.figDesc: with only a few local minima, the dimension of the function is also small. The major difference compared with functions due to their low dimensionalities and a smaller number of local minima. As the results of mean, standard deviation, median, and the worst value is shown in Table3the Hybrid SCA-DE performs better than the other algorithms on nine out of ten of the multimodal low-dimensional benchmark functions for D=10. Box plots of the result of a global minimum of the objective function for 30 independent runs which are computed by using the Hybrid SCA-DE, SCA, PSO, DE and TLBO for functions F1, F3, F13, and F23 are shown in Fig. 8. To confirm the convergence of the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm, two metrics are employed: ï‚· Convergence rate ï‚· Average fitness of all search agents. Figs. 9(a), 9(b) show the convergence rate of the Hybrid SCA-DE, SCA, PSO, DE, and TLBO algorithms for functions F1 to F23. The fitness of the best solution in each iteration is saved and drawn as the convergence curves in Figs. 9(a) and 9(b). The descending trend is quite evident in the convergence curves of Hybrid SCA-DE on many of the test functions investigated. This strongly proves the ability of the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm in obtaining a better approximation of the global optimum over the course of iterations. Figs.10 (a) and 10 (b) shows quantitative measure and average fitness of all search agents in each iteration. If an algorithm improves its solutions, obviously, the average of the fitness should be improved over the course of iterations. As the average fitness curves in Figs.10 (a) and 10 (b) suggest, the Hybrid SCA-DE algorithm shows degrading fitness on all of the test functions. Another fact worth mentioning here is the accelerated decrease in the average fitness curves, which indicates that the improvement of the candidate solutions becomes faster and better over the course of iterations. Figs. 9(a) and 9(b) show how the convergence rate of Hybrid SCA-DE in several cases is better than SCA, PSO, DE, and TLBO algorithms. As stated in Tables
